title: Protocol to visualize the distribution of exogenously administered small molecules in the mouse brain
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Probe injection into a live mouse brain and keeping the mouse free to move
Timing: 1 day
The probe of MOI is injected into a live mouse brain under anesthesia.
Craniotomy.
Inject 200 μL of anesthetic solution into the mouse intraperitoneally.
Wait for the mouse to be anesthetized. Ensure the loss of the pedal withdrawal response.
Remove hairs around the head moistened with 70% EtOH with a shaving knife.
Fix the head to the stereotactic apparatus.
Make an incision in the skin of the head using small surgical scissors.
Place the mouse under the CCD camera.
Determine the target position on the skull using a CCD camera, monitor, and ruler.
Make a small hole in the target area of the skull using a hand drill.
Critical: Apply the drill gently, and be careful not to damage anything other than the skull.
Microinjection.
Fill the glass capillary with paraffin liquid.
Using a microinjector, load the 4.5 μL of probe solution into the glass capillary.
PBS (–) and saline are available as solvents for probe injection.
Insert the glass capillary into the target position.
Inject the whole amount of probe solution into the brain with a microinjector at 600 μL/min.
Recovery from anesthesia.
Remove the mouse from the stereotactic apparatus.
Close the scalp with clips.
Inject an anesthetic antagonist solution intraperitoneally.
Let the mouse move freely in the cage.
Critical: Keep the mouse on the heating pad until it wakes up and moves around on its own. Monitor and keep the mouse in the cage.

Note: To inject a probe into the mouse brain, orient the capillary perpendicular to the surface of the brain, drill a hole in the skull, and insert the capillary following the information in the mouse brain atlas according to the age of the week.2[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2],3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]
Perfusion fixation with 4% PFA solution
Timing: 30 min
PFA penetrates the mouse body to fix tissues and simultaneously immobilize small molecules of interest.
Anesthesia.
Place the mouse in a sealed cage filled with 4% isoflurane.
Wait for the mouse to be anesthetized. Ensure the loss of the pedal withdrawal response.
PFA perfusion (must be done in a fume hood).
Place the mouse on its back on a corkboard in a bat.
Attach an inhaler to the head and flush 4% isoflurane.
Fix both hands and one leg to the corkboard with needles.
Perform a thoracotomy to access the heart.
Insert a needle connected to a peristaltic pump into the left atrium of the mouse.
Make an incision in the right atrial appendage and perfuse with ice-cold 4% PFA 60 mL (three volumes of mouse body weight) in 10 min.
Ensure that the entire body of the mouse is rigid.
Isolate the whole brain using surgical scissors and transfer to 4 mL of ice-cold 4% PFA solution in a 5 mL-size tube.
Post-fixation and sucrose substitution
Timing: 2 days
Soak the tissue in 4% PFA solution overnight at 4°C.
Replace with 30% sucrose solution and soak until the tissue is submerged.
Slice preparation with the cryostat
Timing: 2 h
Immerse tissue block into Tissue-Tek OCT compound in Tissue-Tek Cryomold.
Freeze the sample in the cryostat.
Slice the sample with 20 μm of thickness.
CLSM imaging
Timing: 2 h
Put brain slices on a glass slide and enclose them with cover glass and Fluoromount/Plus.
Image slides with confocal laser scanning microscope.
